Institute of Materials for Energy and Environment College of Materials Science and Engineering Qingdao University Qingdao 266071 China ⁎⁎ Corresponding author. 1 These authors contribute equally to this manuscript Advanced defective structure in Co3O4 catalyst plays a vital role in the boost of catalytic oxidation activity. In this study, a rational defects engineering strategy was developed by precise implanting Ce and Al in the octahedral site of Co3O4, followed by the partial de-doping of the Al atoms. Distorted crystal, abundant oxygen vacancies, higher specific surface area are synergistically incubated by the dual dopants combined with the metal vacancies. The Co3+ O bond could be significantly stimulated to guarantee an excellent methane oxidation activity, with methane conversion rate more than 1.5 times compared with the original Co3O4 catalyst at 300 °C. This work exemplifies the importance of accurate multi-defects manipulation in Co3O4 for intrinsic oxidizability improvement. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Co3O4 Methane oxidation Defects Co-doping Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Resource shortage and environmental pollution are two urgent issues that need to be addressed by humanity at present [1–3]. Particularly, alleviating global warming has become an urgent task worldwide, which necessitates it important for the treatment of greenhouse gases [4,5]. Methane (CH4) with greenhouse effect over 20 times that of CO2, is the second human activity related culprit to heat the earth [6,7]. Therefore, catalytic oxidation of methane tail gas has always been an important topic for the methane involved industrial process, which largely relies on the development of high-performance catalysts. At present, noble metal-based catalysts have demonstrated impressive low-temperature reactivity for pollutant degradation and CH4 catalytic oxidation [8–11]. However, its high cost and poor thermal stability prompted the exploration of efficient non-noble metal catalysts [12]. Co3O4 has become one of the most potential substitutes due to its excellent redox property, variable valence, abundant active oxygen and low price [13–15]. The widely accepted Mv-K mechanism has proven the importance of active surface oxygen species of Co3O4 for the participation in methane oxidation [16,17]. Particularly, Hu et al., pointed out that the octahedral Co3+ site (Co3+ Oh) bonded surface O atoms are more active for the CH bonds activation of CH4 based on experimental study and theory calculations [18]. Thereout, precise modulation of Co3+ Oh-O structure will help improve the catalytic performance of Co3O4 catalyst [19]. Among all the strategies, defects engineering by doping heteroatoms with different atom size and electronegativity points to a promising direction [20,21]. Wen et al. engineered Co3O4 with an elongated Co3+ O bonds through a unique synthetic route, which facilitated the alkane oxidation [19]. Qian et al. reported that partial substitution of Co3+ by Ce could effectively incubate oxygen vacancies (Ov) to induce the creation of more active oxygen species and enhance oxygen mobility, leading to enhanced oxidability [22]. The beneficial effect of Ce doping has also been verified by Choya et al., suggesting that Ce incorporation could improve the redox properties, promoting the CH4 combustion activity [23,24]. Li et al., found that the introduction of Al3+ into the Co3+ site could distort the crystals, intrigue the electron imbalance, and improve the oxidation activity [25]. Our group recently unveiled the function of N doping in Co3O4 to introduce lattice defects and modulate the electron structure of CoO, leading to an excellent CH bond activation ability [26]. Compared to hetero-atom doping, selective atom removal has also recently proven to be another decent defect manipulation strategy. Si et al., selectively dislodged La atom from LaMnO3 perovskite to produce a highly defective MnO2 with abundant surface oxygen species, exerting an excellent CO oxidation performance [27]. Liu et al., adapted NH4+ as sacrificing spatial occupation species, which were selectively eliminated during the calcination procedure to construct a La deficient LaMnO3 catalyst [28]. The tailoring of A-site vacancy in the perovskite could significantly activate the surface oxygen and boost the redox reactions. Moreover, to facilitate the active sites exposure and promote mass transfer, pore architecture design also plays a vital role. A valid way is to build a three-dimensional (3D) interconnected texture so as to provide rich surface area and reactant transmission channels [29]. Based on the above research, a rational multi-defects engineering strategy was developed in this study by Ce, Al co-doping in the octahedral site of 3D mesoporous Co3O4 catalyst combined with partial Al de-doping. An advanced defect site including dual metal doping and metal vacancies synergistically contributed to the stimulation of CoO, guaranteeing a promising CH4 oxidation activity. With systematic characterization, the structure-performance correlation is established, which will instructive for the upgradation of Co3O4 based non-noble metal catalyst for oxidation applications. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of catalysts 2.1.1 Synthesis of KIT-6 The Mesoporous SiO2 template (KIT-6) was synthesized by the solvothermal method. Firstly, 11.8 g of concentrated hydrochloric acid (35 wt.%) was mixed with 217 g of deionized (DI) water and stirred evenly. 6 g of Pluronic P123 (EO20PO70EO20, MW = 5800) was subsequently added to the mixed solution. After stirring at 35 °C for 15 h, 6 g of n-butanol was added, followed by the dropwise addition of 12.9 g of tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS) as the silicon source, which was continuously stirred at 35 °C for 24 h. Then, the mixture was hydrothermally treated at 100 °C for 24 h, followed by the filtration, washing, and drying at 100 °C overnight. The obtained white solid was further purified with 1:10 hydrochloric acid-ethanol mixed solution, and calcined at 550 °C for 6 h to remove the soft template. The final sample was named as KIT-6. 2.1.2 Synthesis of CeAl-Co3O4 catalyst The CeAl-Co3O4 catalyst was synthesized by the equivalent volume impregnation method. 3 g of Co(NO3)2·6H2O, 0.0769 g of Ce(NO3)3·6H2O and 0.3451 g of Al(NO3)3·9H2O was dissolved in 2 mL of DI water. The above solution was dropwise added to 0.2 g of KIT-6 and hand-stirred continuously until the solid is completely soaked, which was followingly calcined at 300 °C for 2 h. The above impregnation and calcination steps are repeated twice to obtain CeAl-Co3O4@KIT-6. To remove the template, 0.4 g of CeAl-Co3O4@KIT-6 was treated in 120 mL of NaOH solution (4 M) under stirring for 6 h at 65 °C, filtered and dried to obtain the final CeAl-Co3O4 catalyst. Co3O4 was synthesized by the similar steps but without adding Ce(NO3)3·6H2O and Al(NO3)3·9H2O. Ce-Co3O4 was prepared by the similar steps but without adding Al(NO3)3·9H2O. And Al-Co3O4 was produced followed by the similar steps but without adding Ce(NO3)3·6H2O. CeO2 was also prepared by the similar procedure with Ce(NO3)3·6H2O as the precursor but without adding any other metal species to serve as the reference catalyst. 2.2 Catalysts characterizations Field emission scanning electron microscope (SEM) and energy dispersion spectrometer (EDS) images were obtained on JEOL JSM-7800F. Specifically, trace samples were dispersed in ethanol under ultrasonication and drop added evenly on the surface of silicon wafers, followed by drying with an infrared baking lamp. Transmission electron microscope (TEM) images were obtained on a JEOL JEM-2100 Specifically, samples were ultrasonically dispersed in ethanol, which was drop added on the surface of a copper mesh and dried by an infrared baking lamp. X-ray diffraction (XRD) pattern was recorded on a Rigaku Ultima IV with Cu-Kα radiation (λ = 0.15418). The 2θ range was set at 10–80° with a counting rate of 5° min−1. Inductively Coupled Plasma (ICP) was tested on Agilent ICP-OES/730. Before ICP test, 5 mg of samples was dissolved by aqua regia and diluted in 100 mL of DI water. N2 physical sorption characterization was performed on Quantachrome Autosorb iQ3 at 77 K with the sample pre-degassed at 120 °C for 8 h. Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) method was used to calculate the specific surface area. The pore size distribution was calculated using the Non-Localized-Density-Functional-Theory (NL-DFT) and Barrett–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) methods, respectively. The total pore volume was calculated at P/P0 = 0.9997. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was obtained by a PHI5000 Versaprobe III XPS spectrometer with an Al Kα X-ray source at the working conditions with pressure of 6 × 10−7 kPa, working voltage of 10 kV and working current of 5 mA. Raman scattering spectra were recorded on a Renishaw in Via Plus Micro-Raman spectroscopy system equipped with a 50 mW DPSS laser at 532 nm. Electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) measurements were recorded on an FA-200 (JES) electron paramagnetic resonance spectrometer. 2.3 Catalytic activity evaluation The methane catalytic combustion was carried out on a micro-reactor. At atmospheric pressure, 0.1 g of catalyst was loaded into the center of the quartz reaction tube with a diameter of 6 mm, and the sample was paved with a small amount of quartz cotton. The reaction gas contains 2 vol.% CH4, 21 vol.% O2 and is balanced with Ar. The total gas flow used is 66 mL min−1, which corresponds to total weight hourly space velocity (WHSV) of 40,000 mL g−1 h−1. The reaction temperature was increased from 50 °C to 700 °C at a rate of 2 °C min−1. The gas chromatograph (Shimadzu, GC-2014) equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD), hydrogen flame ionization detector (FID) and a KB-plot Q GC column was used for online analysis of tail gas components. The conversion of CH4 was calculated using the following formula: C H 4 conversion ( % ) = [ C H 4 ] in − [ C H 4 ] out [ C H 4 ] in × 100 % where [CH4] in and [CH4] out represent the concentration of CH4 at the inlet and outlet of the reactor, respectively. In order to have a fair comparison of the catalytic activity with the reported catalyst, the CH4 conversion rate r ( C H 4 ) was calculated with the following equation: r ( C H 4 ) = F × C ( C H 4 ) × Con v ( C H 4 ) 22.4 × 10 3 mL / mol × m cat . where F is gaseous total flow rate, c ( C H 4 ) is the concentration of CH4, Con v ( C H 4 ) represent the CH4 conversion and mcat. is the mass of the catalysts. 3 Results and discussion As the TEM image shown in Fig. 1 (a), a 3D structured CeAl-Co3O4 was synthesized using KIT-6 as the hard template, which demonstrated a uniform mesoporous texture with pore size less than 10 nm. The HR-TEM in Fig. 1(b)–(d) shows that the CeAl-Co3O4 consists of (220) and (111) crystal faces with lattice spacing of 0.286 nm and 0.467 nm, respectively [30]. The SEM and the corresponding EDX elemental mapping in Fig. 1(e)–(i) showed that O, Co, Al and Ce atoms are uniformly distributed in the framework of the catalyst, indicating that the Ce and Al atoms may be evenly doped in the crystal structure. The SEM and TEM images of Co3O4, Ce-Co3O4 and Al-Co3O4 in Figs. S1–S3 show the same morphology as CeAl-Co3O4, the successful doping of Ce or Al is shown in the elemental EDX mapping, respectively. As for the proportion of doping, the doped Ce is detected to be 2.71 wt.% by the ICP test, which is similar to the theoretical doping amount of 3 wt.%. However, the actual amount of Al is 0.86 wt.%, which is much less than the theoretical doping amount of 3 wt.%. This indicates that some of Al atoms were inevitably etched by alkali washing during the template removal process, which may lead to the creation of metal vacancies. The XRD spectra of the catalysts in Fig. 2 (a) shows diffraction peaks at 19.0°, 31.3°, 36.9°, 44.8°, 59.4° and 65.2°, which correspond to the (111), (220), (311), (400), (511) and (440) lattice of the Co3O4 spinel structure (JCPDS of 42-1467), respectively, indicating that the spinel crystal structure is well preserved after the heteroatom doping without forming bulk Ce and Al oxides. It is interesting to find that the diffraction peak of the (311) crystal plane has a slight shift to a small angle after Ce doping, indicating that the lattice has been expanded, which may be caused by the larger ion radius of Ce3+ (1.15 Å) compared to that of Co3+ (0.89 Å) (Fig. 2(b)). While the peak for the Al-containing catalyst showed an obviously shifts to a high angle, suggesting that the catalyst has obvious lattice shrinkage after Al doping, which may be caused by the formation of metal vacancies induced by the Al atom de-doping [31]. Raman spectrum was carried out to shed light on the crystal defects. As can be seen in Fig. 2(c), characteristic peaks at 683 cm−1, 610 cm−1, 519 cm−1, 475 cm−1 and 197 cm−1 are detected, which are in accordance with A1g symmetry mode, F1g 3 mode, F1g 2 mode, Eg mode and F1g 1 mode of spinel Co3O4, respectively. Among them, A1g is related to the crystal vibration of octahedral sites [32,33]. It can be found that A1g peak for the doped catalysts have a prominent shift compared to that of Co3O4 catalyst. And the A1g peak deviation is the most for CeAl-Co3O4, which means that the Ce and Al co-doping combined Al de-doping created tremendous structure defects (crystal distortion, lattice compression, etc.). To explore the oxygen vacancy content of the catalysts qualitatively, electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) was conducted with the peak (g = 2.003) offering the information of O v [34]. It can be seen from Fig. 2(d) that the peak intensity of CeAl-Co3O4 is the highest, followed by Ce-Co3O4, Al-Co3O4 and Co3O4. This indicates that the dual-atom doping and de-doping procedure is intriguing for the O v implantation, which will play an important role in oxidation activity improvement. N2 physical sorption experiment was carried out to explore the pore structure of the catalyst. The N2 sorption isotherm in Fig. 3 (a) shows typical IV-type curves with standard H2 hysteresis loop, suggesting the rich mesoporous structure [35]. In addition, NL-DFT pore size distribution in Fig. 3(b) demonstrated that pore sizes of all samples are mainly centered at around 3.3 nm, further confirming the mesoporous texture. It is interesting to find that the mean pore size is slightly enlarged after doping Ce, Al atoms and Al-Co3O4 has the largest pore size of 3.6 nm, which may be due to the creation of structure defects by the partial removal of Al atom. BJH method, which is suitable for the analysis of mesopore structure was further applied to consolidate the pore size information. The result was shown in Fig. S4, which is well in line with the NL-DFT analysis. As shown in Table 1 , the specific surface area (SSA) follows CeAl-Co3O4 > Al-Co3O4 > Ce-Co3O4 > Co3O4. CeAl-Co3O4 having more defects showed the largest specific surface area and pore volume (Table 1), which will be beneficial for the active site exposure and mass transfer. The surface information of the catalyst was analyzed by XPS. As shown in Fig. 3(c), O 1s XPS spectrum can be fitted into peaks at about 531.1 eV and 529.2 eV, corresponding to surface oxygen (Osurf) and lattice oxygen (Olatt), separately [36]. It can be seen from Table 1 that CeAl-Co3O4 has a prominent higher proportion of with the Osurf/Olatt ratio of 1.22, much higher than that of Al-Co3O4 (0.73), Ce-Co3O4 (0.72) and Co3O4 (0.62), strongly proving that the defects engineering procedure help creation of oxygen vacancy lattice defects to incubate more surface oxygen species [19]. In Fig. 3(d), the XPS spectrum of Co 2p was composed of two main peaks at 778.0 eV and 793.5 eV, corresponding to Co 2p3/2 and Co 2p1/2, which can be fitted into characteristic peaks corresponding to Co3+ (779.4 eV and 794.0 eV) and Co2+ (780.7 eV and 796.0 eV), respectively [37]. As can be seen from Fig. 3(d) and Table 1 that the Co2+/Co3+ ratio for the de-convoluted Co 2p3/2 peak of CeAl-Co3O4 (1.68) is far greater than that of Co3O4 (0.77). This phenomenon indicates that the doping of Al replaces some of the Co3+, and the doping and partial de-doping procedure can reduce the average valence of Co, thus generating more oxygen vacancies, which is consistent with the results of Raman spectrum in Fig. 2(c) [38]. Ce-Co3O4 and Al-Co3O4 with different dopant content were synthesized and evaluated for the methane oxidation reaction. As shown in Fig. S5(a), 3 wt.% Ce is the optimized doping ratio. The temperature corresponding to 90 % methane conversion (T90) of 3 wt.% Ce-doped sample (Ce-Co3O4) is better than that of 1 wt.% and 5 wt.% Ce-doped samples. Similarly, Fig. S5(b) shows that 3 wt.% Al doping is more active than other doping amounts. In order to explain the influence of doping amount on the catalytic performance, the crystal and surface structure of the doped catalyst were characterized. From the XRD pattern in Figs. S6(a), (b), it can be seen that the main XRD peak at 2θ of around 37° shifted to a lower value after 1 wt.%Ce doping, and the shift is enhanced for 3 wt.% Ce doped sample, which may be caused by the lattice expansion via replacing Co atom by larger-sized Ce in the crystal lattice. However, the 5 wt.% Ce doped sample shows a back shift for the main XRD peak. This could be due to that excess Ce could form CeO2 particles on the surface of Co3O4 (as evidenced in XRD pattern in Fig. S6(a)) [24], inhibiting the Ce doping in the spinel crystals. The reference catalyst of CeO2 was tested for methane oxidation reaction, which showed a very poor activity as shown in Fig. S7. This result could also be supported by other literatures, reporting the inferior oxidation ability of CeO2 for alkane [39]. Therefore, 5 % Ce doped Co3O4 showed a decreased methane oxidation activity. In comparison, Al doping induced the main XRD peak shifting to a higher binding energy due to the crystal shrinkage with the replacing of Co by smaller Al atom. Similarly, excess Al doping leads to the back shift of the main XRD peak. This could also be due to the formation of AlOx on the surface of Co3O4, which however is too small to be detected by the XRD characterization. Consequently, the 4 %Al-Co3O4 shows inferior methane oxidation activity. The Raman characterizations (Fig. S8) further verified that the 3 %Ce-Co3O4 and 3 %Al-Co3O4 has the largest peak variation, which sufficiently proved the abundant defects structure (lattice distortion, crystal stress etc.) created with 3 wt.% Ce and 3 wt.% Al doping. Furthermore, the XPS characterizations were carried out to shed light on the information of active surface oxygen species. From Fig. S9 and Table S1, it can be identified that the Osurf ratio of 3 %Ce-Co3O4 and 3 %Al-Co3O4 is highest compared to other samples. All in all, doping 3 wt.% Ce and 3 wt.% Al separately in Co3O4 may achieve the optimal defects structure and facilitate greatly the generation of active oxygen species, thereout delivering a superior methane oxidation activity. The CH4 catalytic combustion performance of co-doped samples with the optimal doping amount was compared with those of single doped Ce, Al samples. From Fig. 4 (a) and Table 2 , it can be seen that CeAl-Co3O4 showed a remarkable methane oxidation activity with T50 of 276 °C and T90 of 350 °C, significantly superior to that of Co3O4 (T50 = 302 °C, T90 = 427 °C). Interestingly, the T90 of CeAl-Co3O4 is almost the same as that of Ce-Co3O4 (351 °C) and Al-Co3O4 (350 °C), while the T50 is still lower than that of Ce-Co3O4 (289 °C) and Al-Co3O4 (297 °C), which suggests that the Co3+ site defects are more beneficial for the low temperature oxidation ability improvement. The conversion rate of methane on the catalyst at 300 °C was further calculated, demonstrating that CeAl-Co3O4 has a methane conversion rate 1.5 times that of the original Co3O4 catalyst (Fig. 4(b)). Moreover, by comparing the CH4 oxidation performance with other catalysts at T90 of CeAl-Co3O4 (350 °C), it can be found that CeAl-Co3O4 shows one of the most remarkable oxidation activity (Table 3 ). This sufficiently proves the effectiveness of the defects engineering strategy of doping and de-doping for intrinsic oxidation ability improvement. Last but not the least, the stability of CeAl-Co3O4 was tested at reaction temperature of 350 °C (T90). It can be seen that the methane conversion is decreased by about 15 % after 24 h continuous reaction (Fig. S10). The poor stability could be due to the fragility of the defective structure of CeAl-Co3O4, which underwent pore collapse after the stability test as the TEM characterization in Fig. S11. Therefore, efficient strategies to sustain the catalytic performance of the defective catalyst should be further investigated in the following work. 4 Conclusions In this work, an ingenious dual atom doping and partial de-doping was controllably manipulated to produce a defective 3D structured CeAl-Co3O4 catalyst containing both dopant and vacancy at the octahedral cobalt site. The high specific surface area helps the exposure of active surface oxygen. The abundant lattice defects (structure distortion, oxygen vacancies, etc.) promote the oxygen mobility. Meanwhile, the 3D mesoporous structure facilitates the kinetic mass transfer. Consequently, an impressive methane oxidation activity was guaranteed for CeAl-Co3O4. This work will provide a novel defects engineering strategy for the oxidation activity upgradation, which will be attractive for the promotion of noble metal replacement for methane oxidation and other reaction. coredata.dc:description: Advanced defective structure in Co3O4 catalyst plays a vital role in the boost of catalytic oxidation activity. In this study, a rational defects engineering strategy was developed by precise implanting Ce and Al in the octahedral site of Co3O4, followed by the partial de-doping of the Al atoms. Distorted crystal, abundant oxygen vacancies, higher specific surface area are synergistically incubated by the dual dopants combined with the metal vacancies. The Co3+ O bond could be significantly stimulated to guarantee an excellent methane oxidation activity, with methane conversion rate more than 1.5 times compared with the original Co3O4 catalyst at 300 °C. This work exemplifies the importance of accurate multi-defects manipulation in Co3O4 for intrinsic oxidizability improvement.
coredata.dc:title: Engineering defective Co3O4 containing both metal doping and vacancy in octahedral cobalt site as high performance catalyst for methane oxidation
